title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea, missing since 1988, was identified through DNA testing after his remains were found in Newburyport.
Rea's aunt, Carolann Angelli, and Maya Ambrose seek to repatriate his remains for a family burial.
A GoFundMe campaign raised nearly $3,000 to cover costs for burying Rea with his family.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com's latest news quiz includes questions about Hasbro, Aroldis Chapman, and local celebrities Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.
The quiz aims to engage readers with trending stories in Greater Boston, testing their local news knowledge.
Peter Chianca, Boston.com’s general assignment editor, contributed to the AI-assisted formulation of the quiz questions.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman may opt out of his Red Sox contract after the 2025 season to explore free agency.
Red Sox president Sam Kennedy claims both Bregman and the team are committed despite opt-out rumors.
Bregman focuses on playoffs, deferring contract discussions, with a batting average of .279, 16 HRs, 57 RBIs in 101 games.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick stated in a new book that Tom Brady made the 'right decision' to leave the Patriots in 2020.
Belichick admitted the Patriots couldn't provide a strong team around Brady due to financial constraints and team rebuilding.
Brady led the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to a Super Bowl in his first season, thriving with a deeper roster than in New England.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Ryan sues West Boylston for wrongful termination, seeking over $1.3 million, claiming retaliation over a Trump flag dispute.
Ryan fired following conflict with Police Chief Dennis Minnich, who refused flag removal due to ethics concerns.
Police Chief Minnich asserts compliance with flag removal; the Select Board voted 4-1 to terminate Ryan.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old was severely burned while attempting a TikTok challenge in North Smithfield, R.I., on September 6.
The challenge involved pouring gasoline, lighting themselves on fire, and jumping into Slatersville Reservoir with a 16-year-old friend.
The injured man was hospitalized with second- and third-degree burns; no charges filed for trespassing on private property.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett officials canceled Fiesta Del Rio, a Hispanic Heritage Month event, due to recent ICE raids in the area.
The festival, set for September 20, aimed to celebrate Hispanic culture with live music, art, and local food vendors.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria emphasized the decision to prioritize community safety and the city’s commitment to future diversity celebrations.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his mayoral campaign after losing to Mayor Michelle Wu by nearly 50 points in the preliminary election.
Kraft out-raised Wu, collecting over $6.8 million, including $5.5 million of his own funds for the campaign.
Kraft announced a $3 million donation to address a humanitarian crisis in Boston after suspending his mayoral bid.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh McDaniels expressed confidence in Drake Maye as the New England Patriots' quarterback despite a poor season opener.
Drake Maye threw an interception in the second half in a Week 1 loss to the Raiders, drawing criticism.
McDaniels emphasized Maye's need to gain experience, noting learning a new offensive system takes time.

title: Authorities in a Connecticut town want to speak with whoever is painting the squirrels
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Two squirrels in East Hartford, Connecticut, were painted red and blue near Naubuc Avenue and High Street.
East Hartford Animal Control officers are collaborating with a wildlife rehabilitator to aid the painted squirrels.
Authorities request information about the incident; people can call 860-291-7572 to report details.
